thread.title: Funeral for slain RTD officer focuses on his faith, boundless love for family, commitment to mission
thread.title_full: Funeral for slain RTD officer focuses on his faith, boundless love for family, commitment to mission

author: Hayley Sanchez
title: Funeral for slain RTD officer focuses on his faith, boundless love for family, commitment to mission
text:
Hundreds of American flags planted in the lawn of Resurrection Church in Loveland welcomed mourners gathering Monday morning to pay tribute to Scott Von Lanken, the contract RTD security officer gunned down last week outside Denver Union Station.
Von Lanken’s friends and family were greeted inside the church by hundreds of lawmen and women from agencies in Boulder and Larimer counties, the Regional Transportation District, Aurora and his employer Allied Universal.
“He was a mountain man and loved camping,” said pastor Paulette Blaylock, who officiated the service for her friend, who also was a charismatic Christian preacher. “He loved God and his words, and the word flowed out of his mouth like a special gift. Scott will not be forgotten.” 
She spoke of the depth of Von Lanken’s faith and his love for his wife, Shellie, and their twin daughters Cassie and Crystal Von Lanken. Von Lanken and his wife, Shellie, were never seen apart, Blaylock said. They traveled by motorcycle to California, Arizona and Yellowstone National Park.

Blaylock also read aloud an emotional letter Cassie wrote to her father, in which she reminisced about making snow angels with her dad and sister, and thanking him for loving their family.
“Like an eagle, you had a vision that reached over every territorial terrain and reached the horizon of every glorious sunset and morning dawn,” Cassie wrote of her dad, who she said loved eagles. “Like an eagle sometimes you would fly alone confident in the course of your creator’s plan… Thank you for loving God more than life itself.”
Von Lanken, 56, was killed late the night of Jan. 31, shot in the head as he gave directions to two women who were trying to find their light rail train. His alleged killer was arrested about a half hour later and is being held without bail in Denver’s downtown detention center.
RTD commander John Perry described Von Lanken, a former La Crosse, Wis., police officer who had worked RTD security for about six years, as a great leader who was positive and had uplifting thoughts. He said he would often get caught up talking to Von Lanken as he was leaving work for the day.
“It seemed like every evening I was leaving the building during the nights that Scott worked, I would be drawn in by him for a 30 minute discussion about life, faith, family and the current hot topic of the week,” he said. “When I heard about the circumstances that surrounded Scott’s death, it was no surprise to me that he was interacting with two of our patrons and giving them directions. This type of interaction was his speciality.”
Perry grew more emotional as continued to speak about Von Lanken and said he made service to others his mission and truly represented the intent of a first responder’s job.
“Service to others in our profession is why we all do what we do on a daily basis,” he said. “Scott made it easy to leave his legacy in all of us. We will never forget you. God bless you, my friend.”
After the service, Von Lanken’s remains were taken to Estes Park Memorial Garden for burial.
